files.README.md:
# Obsidian Sync Plans Plugin 

A Claude Code plugin that copies plan files into your Obsidian vault with YAML frontmatter, so you can query them with Dataview.

This is a plugin for [Claude Code](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code) (Anthropic's Claude CLI). It's not an Obsidian community plugin.

## Why

Claude Code stores plan files in `~/.claude/plans/` — useful but invisible to everything else on your machine. This plugin syncs those plans into your Obsidian vault with YAML frontmatter (timestamps, project, branch, tags), so Dataview can query, filter, and surface them alongside your other notes.

## Prerequisites

- [Obsidian](https://obsidian.md/) with a local vault
- [Dataview](https://github.com/blacksmithgu/obsidian-dataview) community plugin (required for dashboard/MOC queries)

## Installation

### Quick Install (Claude Code)

```
/plugin https://github.com/jackhutson/obsidian-sync-plugin.git
```

### Manual Install (Claude Code)

Clone the repo and install from the local path:

```
git clone https://github.com/jackhutson/obsidian-sync-plugin.git
/plugin /path/to/obsidian-sync-plugin
```

All commands and hooks work identically to the quick install.

### Standalone / Cursor

Clone the repo and run the bash scripts directly — no Claude Code required:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/jackhutson/obsidian-sync-plugin.git
cd obsidian-sync-plugin

bash hooks/scripts/configure.sh
bash hooks/scripts/sync.sh [--all] [--no-open] [--dry-run]
bash hooks/scripts/install-dashboards.sh
```

**What works:** manual sync, configure wizard, dashboard installer, config file.

**What doesn't:** auto-sync hooks and slash commands (these require the Claude Code plugin runtime).

> **Tip:** Wire `bash /path/to/obsidian-sync-plugin/hooks/scripts/sync.sh --all --no-open` into a Cursor task or keybinding for one-key syncing.

## Quick Start

1. Run `/obsidian-sync:configure` and enter your vault path
2. Sync your latest plan: `/obsidian-sync:sync`
3. Or sync everything: `/obsidian-sync:sync --all`

Plans land in a `Claude Plans` subfolder (configurable) with frontmatter attached. From there Dataview can pick them up.

## Commands

| Command | What it does |
|---------|-------------|
| `/obsidian-sync:configure` | Configuration wizard — vault path, sync trigger, etc. |
| `/obsidian-sync:sync` | Sync the most recent plan and open it in Obsidian |
| `/obsidian-sync:sync --all` | Sync all plans from configured paths |
| `/obsidian-sync:sync --dry-run` | Show what would sync without writing anything |
| `/obsidian-sync:sync --no-open` | Sync without opening Obsidian |
| `/obsidian-sync:install-dashboards` | Install a Dataview MOC (Map of Content) to your plans folder |

## Configuration

Run `/obsidian-sync:configure` for a guided setup, or edit the config file manually. Settings live in `.claude/obsidian-sync.local.md` (project-level is checked first, then `~/.claude/obsidian-sync.local.md` as a fallback). The file uses YAML frontmatter:

```yaml
---
vault_path: "~/Documents/Obsidian/MyVault"
plans_folder: "Claude Plans"
enabled: true
sync_trigger: on_write
plan_paths:
  - ~/.claude/plans/*.md
  - .claude/plans/*.md
tags:
  - claude-code
  - plan
  - auto-synced
---
```

### Sync Triggers

| Trigger | Behavior |
|---------|----------|
| `on_write` | Sync each plan file the moment it's written (default) |
| `on_task_complete` | Sync all plans when a task is marked completed |
| `on_session_end` | Sync all plans when the Claude Code session ends |
| `manual` | Only sync via `/obsidian-sync:sync` |

### Plan Paths

By default the plugin watches `~/.claude/plans/*.md` and `.claude/plans/*.md`. Add more patterns under `plan_paths` — relative paths resolve from the project root, and `*` wildcards work.

### Config Format Notes

The config parser is intentionally simple. A few things to keep in mind:

- Values containing `:` should be quoted (`plans_folder: "My: Folder"`)
- No nested YAML — only flat key/value pairs and arrays
- Arrays must use the `  - value` format (two-space indent, dash, space)

## Synced File Format

Each synced file gets frontmatter like this:

```yaml
---
created: "2025-01-15T10:30:00Z"
source: "~/.claude/plans/session-abc123.md"
synced: "2025-01-15T14:45:00Z"
working_dir: "~/projects/my-app"
project: "my-app"
branch: "feature/new-feature"
tags:
  - claude-code
  - plan
  - auto-synced
---
```

`project` and `branch` only appear when syncing from inside a git repo. The `created` timestamp is preserved across re-syncs.

## Dataview

A common starting point with the [Dataview](https://github.com/blacksmithgu/obsidian-dataview) plugin:

```dataview
TABLE created, project, branch
FROM #claude-code
SORT created DESC
LIMIT 10
```

For more queries (by project, today's plans, weekly summaries), run `/obsidian-sync:install-dashboards` to drop a ready-made MOC into your plans folder.

## Troubleshooting

**Plans not syncing automatically?**
Check that `enabled: true` is set in your config, the vault path exists, and `sync_trigger` matches what you expect. Run `/obsidian-sync:sync --dry-run --all` to see what would be synced.

**Vault path not found?**
Run `/obsidian-sync:configure` to update it. The wizard validates the path.

**Missing `project` or `branch` fields?**
These only populate when you're inside a git repository.

**Scripts won't run? (standalone users)**
Make sure a config file exists at `.claude/obsidian-sync.local.md` or `~/.claude/obsidian-sync.local.md`. If you haven't run `configure.sh` yet, do that first. Also check that the scripts have execute permissions (`chmod +x hooks/scripts/*.sh`).

## License

MIT

files.README.md:
# todoist-mcp-plugin

Every MCP server you enable in Claude Code injects tool definitions into your system prompt — consuming context in every message, even when idle. The official Todoist MCP adds ~8-10 tool schemas (~2,500 tokens). This plugin wraps it in a subagent so those definitions never touch your main conversation.

## How It Works

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  Main Claude Code Conversation                  │
│                                                 │
│  Skills loaded on demand:                       │
│  ┌─────────────┐  ┌──────────────┐              │
│  │todoist-tasks │  │ todoist-sync │  ~50-80 tok  │
│  │  (metadata)  │  │  (metadata)  │  idle cost   │
│  └──────┬──────┘  └──────┬───────┘              │
│         │                │                      │
│         └───────┬────────┘                      │
│                 ▼                                │
│  ┌──────────────────────────────┐               │
│  │      todoist-agent           │               │
│  │   (separate context window)  │               │
│  │                              │               │
│  │  MCP tool definitions live   │               │
│  │  HERE, not in main context   │               │
│  │                              │               │
│  │  ┌────────────────────────┐  │               │
│  │  │ Doist MCP (HTTP/OAuth) │  │               │
│  │  │ ai.todoist.net/mcp     │  │               │
│  │  └────────────────────────┘  │               │
│  └──────────────────────────────┘               │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

Skills expose only short metadata descriptions to the main context (~50-80 tokens). When triggered, the full skill body loads and delegates to a subagent that holds the MCP connection in its own context window. Tool schemas stay isolated.

### Token Cost Comparison

| Setup | Idle Context Cost | Per-Operation Cost |
|-------|------------------|--------------------|
| Raw MCP (always loaded) | ~2,500 tokens/message (tool schemas in every message) | Same + API response |
| This plugin | ~50-80 tokens/message (skill metadata only) | ~900 tokens (skill body) + subagent |

Over a 50-message coding session, raw MCP costs 100k-150k tokens on Todoist schemas you used twice. This plugin pays only when you use it.

## Quick Start

```bash
claude plugin install jackhutson/todoist-mcp-plugin
```

Then authenticate with the Todoist MCP server:

1. Launch Claude Code
2. Run `/mcp`
3. Select the `todoist` server
4. Complete the browser-based OAuth flow

No API keys to manage — the official Doist server uses OAuth.

## Usage

Natural language, delegated automatically:

```
"Add a task 'Review PR #42' to Work with p2 priority due tomorrow"
"What's due today?"
"Mark the deploy task as done"
"Refresh my Todoist projects"
```

## Supported Operations

- **Task CRUD** — create, complete, update, delete
- **Queries** — by project, priority, due date, label, or Todoist filter strings
- **Structure sync** — projects, sections, labels fetched and cached in-conversation
- **Error recovery** — automatic re-sync on name resolution failures

## Design Principles

- **Subagent isolation** — MCP tool definitions never enter the main context window
- **Progressive disclosure** — skill metadata always loaded; full instructions only when triggered
- **Cache-first** — Todoist structure synced once per session, reused across operations
- **Official MCP** — uses Doist's own server (`ai.todoist.net/mcp`) with fewer, workflow-oriented tools and OAuth auth

## Requirements

- Claude Code with plugin support
- Todoist account (free or Pro)

## License

MIT
